facts.text: (1819) Capital: Montgomery.
Home to the Unclaimed Baggage Center, where lost airline luggage is sold.
Birthplace of the Saturn V rocket that took humans to the moon.
It has an official 'State Spirit': Conecuh Ridge Whiskey.
Windshield wipers were invented here by Mary Anderson in 1903.
(1959) Capital: Juneau.
Boasts a coastline longer than all other 49 states combined.
The name 'Alaska' can be typed on just one row of a QWERTY keyboard.
Experience 80 days of midnight sun in Barrow.
The U.S. purchased it from Russia for just 2 cents an acre.
There are more caribou than people.
(1912) Capital: Phoenix.
The only state where Saguaro cacti grow wild.
Home to the original London Bridge (bought and moved to Lake Havasu).
The official state neckwear is the Bolo tie.
It does not observe Daylight Saving Time (except the Navajo Nation).
(1836) Capital: Little Rock.
Home to the only active diamond mine in the US open to the public.
Sam Walton opened the first Walmart here in 1962.
Cheese dip was allegedly invented here in 1935.
Contains the naturally hottest springs in the country.
(1850) Capital: Sacramento.
Home to the General Sherman tree, the largest living thing on Earth.
If it were a country, it would be the 5th largest economy in the world.
Produces 80% of the world's almonds.
Death Valley is the hottest, driest, and lowest place in North America.
(1876) Capital: Denver.
The 13th step of the state capitol is exactly one mile above sea level.
The only state to turn down hosting the Olympics (1976 Winter Games).
The cheeseburger trademark was first awarded here in 1935.
Has the highest mean altitude of any state.
(1788) Capital: Hartford.
Home to the first phone book (it only had 50 names).
The first hamburger was served at Louis' Lunch in New Haven.
Home to the USS Nautilus, the world's first nuclear submarine.
The Scoville Scale for measuring chili heat was invented here.
(1787) Capital: Dover.
The 'First State'â€”it was the first to ratify the Constitution.
There is no sales tax, making it a shopping destination.
More corporations are incorporated here than there are people.
The spacesuit was developed here by ILC Dover.
(1845) Capital: Tallahassee.
The only place where alligators and crocodiles coexist in the wild.
Key West once declared war on the US as the 'Conch Republic'.
The flattest state in the nation.
Gatorade was invented at the University of Florida.
The lightning capital of the United States.
(1788) Capital: Atlanta.
Coca-Cola was invented here by a pharmacist in 1886.
Vidalia onions can legally only be grown in 20 counties here.
Hosted the 1996 Summer Olympics.
The Masters golf tournament is played in Augusta every year.
(1959) Capital: Honolulu.
The only state that grows coffee commercially.
Has the only royal palace in the US (Iolani Palace).
Billboards are banned state-wide to preserve the view.
The state consists of 132 different islands.
Snakes are illegal here.
(1890) Capital: Boise.
Produces about one-third of all potatoes grown in the US.
Hells Canyon is deeper than the Grand Canyon.
Television was invented here by Philo Farnsworth in a high school lab.
The state capital is geothermal, heated by underground hot springs.
(1818) Capital: Springfield.
The world's first skyscraper was built in Chicago in 1885.
Twinkies were invented here during the Great Depression.
The Chicago River is dyed green every St. Patrick's Day.
Route 66 begins in Chicago.
(1816) Capital: Indianapolis.
Home to the Indy 500, the largest single-day sporting event.
The town of Santa Claus receives half a million letters a year.
Produces more popcorn than any other state.
The first professional baseball game was played here in 1871.
(1846) Capital: Des Moines.
Sliced bread was invented here by Otto Rohwedder in 1928.
There are more pigs than people (about 7 to 1).
Snake Alley is known as the 'Crookedest Street in the World'.
The 'Field of Dreams' movie set is still a tourist attraction.
(1861) Capital: Topeka.
Helium was discovered here in 1905.
Pizza Hut was founded here by two brothers in 1958.
Produces enough wheat in a year to bake 36 billion loaves of bread.
Dodge City is known as the 'Cowboy Capital of the World'.
(1792) Capital: Frankfort.
Produces 95% of the world's bourbon.
Mammoth Cave is the world's longest cave system.
The 'Happy Birthday' song was created here.
The Chevrolet Corvette is manufactured exclusively here.
(1812) Capital: Baton Rouge.
The only state divided into 'parishes' instead of counties.
The birthplace of Jazz music.
Tabasco sauce has been made on Avery Island since 1868.
Has the tallest state capitol building in the US.
(1820) Capital: Augusta.
Harvests 90% of the country's lobster supply.
The closest US state to Africa.
The only state name with just one syllable.
Produces 99% of all blueberries in the US.
(1788) Capital: Annapolis.
The US National Anthem was written here at Fort McHenry.
The official state sport is Jousting.
The Ouija board was named here (allegedly by the board itself).
Home to the first dental school in the world.
(1788) Capital: Boston.
Basketball was invented here by James Naismith in 1891.
Harvard is the oldest institution of higher learning in the US.
Chocolate chip cookies were invented at the Toll House Inn.
The first subway system in America opened here in 1897.
(1837) Capital: Lansing.
The only state that touches four of the five Great Lakes.
Battle Creek is known as the 'Cereal Capital of the World'.
Home to the only floating post office in the world (the J.W. Westcott II).
The Model T was first mass-produced here by Ford.
(1858) Capital: St. Paul.
Known as the 'Land of 10,000 Lakes' (actually has 11,842).
The Mall of America is big enough to fit 7 Yankee Stadiums.
Scotch Tape and Post-It Notes were invented here at 3M.
Water skiing was invented here in 1922.
(1817) Capital: Jackson.
Root beer was invented here by Edward Barq in 1898.
The name 'Teddy Bear' originated here after a T. Roosevelt hunting trip.
Produces 60% of the farm-raised catfish in the US.
The first heart and lung transplant was performed here.
(1821) Capital: Jefferson City.
The Gateway Arch is the tallest man-made monument in the US.
Ice cream cones were popularized here at the 1904 World's Fair.
Shares a border with 8 different states (tied with TN).
Home to Anheuser-Busch, one of the world's largest breweries.
(1889) Capital: Helena.
The 'Big Sky Country' has a larger grizzly bear population than humans.
Triple Divide Peak sends water to three different oceans.
The Roe River is one of the world's shortest rivers (201 ft).
It has the largest migratory elk herd in the nation.
(1867) Capital: Lincoln.
Kool-Aid was invented here by Edwin Perkins in 1927.
Home to Carhenge, a replica of Stonehenge made of vintage cars.
The only state with a unicameral (one-house) legislature.
Arbor Day was founded here in 1872.
(1864) Capital: Carson City.
The most mountainous state in the US (over 300 ranges).
Las Vegas has more hotel rooms than any other city on Earth.
Home to Area 51, a highly classified Air Force facility.
85% of the state is owned by the federal government.
(1788) Capital: Concord.
Holds the first primary in the US presidential election cycle.
Mt. Washington held the world record for wind speed (231 mph) for decades.
The first free public library in the US was established here.
License plates famously read 'Live Free or Die'.
(1787) Capital: Trenton.
Has the most diners in the world and is often called the 'Diner Capital'.
Atlantic City has the longest boardwalk in the world.
Salt water taffy was invented here in the 1880s.
Thomas Edison invented the lightbulb at his Menlo Park lab.
(1912) Capital: Santa Fe.
Santa Fe is the highest and oldest state capital in the US.
The first atomic bomb was detonated here at the Trinity site.
Hosts the largest hot air balloon festival in the world.
Smokey Bear was found here as a cub after a forest fire.
(1788) Capital: Albany.
Home to the first pizzeria in the US (Lombardi's, 1905).
The Federal Reserve Bank holds more gold than Fort Knox.
Toilet paper was invented here in 1857.
Yellow taxis were chosen because yellow is the easiest color to spot.
Adirondack Park is larger than Yellowstone, Yosemite, and Grand Canyon combined.
(1789) Capital: Raleigh.
The Wright Brothers made the first powered flight here in 1903.
Pepsi was invented here in New Bern in 1893.
Krispy Kreme Doughnuts was founded here in 1937.
Home to the 'Lost Colony' of Roanoke.
(1889) Capital: Bismarck.
The town of Rugby is the geographical center of North America.
It is consistently the least visited state in the US.
Holds the Guinness World Record for the most snow angels made at once.
Produces more honey than any other state.
(1803) Capital: Columbus.
Home to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.
Produced 25 NASA astronauts, including Neil Armstrong and John Glenn.
The first ambulance service was established here in 1865.
50% of the US population lives within a 500-mile radius of Columbus.
(1907) Capital: Oklahoma City.
The shopping cart was invented here in 1937.
The parking meter was invented here (first installed in 1935).
The movie 'Twister' was based on the NOAA lab here.
It has the largest Native American population of any state.
(1859) Capital: Salem.
Crater Lake is the deepest lake in the US.
Nike was founded here (originally as Blue Ribbon Sports).
Home to the world's smallest park (Mill Ends Park, 2 feet wide).
It has no state sales tax.
(1787) Capital: Harrisburg.
Hershey is known as the 'Chocolate Capital of the World'.
The Declaration of Independence was signed in Philadelphia.
Home to the first zoo in America (Philadelphia Zoo).
The Slinky was invented here.
(1790) Capital: Providence.
The smallest US state (only 1,214 square miles).
Coffee Milk is the official state drink.
Home to the oldest operating tavern in the US (White Horse Tavern).
Founded by Roger Williams on the principle of religious freedom.
(1788) Capital: Columbia.
The first state to secede from the Union in 1860.
Birthplace of Sweet Tea.
Morgan Island is inhabited by over 3,000 free-ranging monkeys.
Produces more peaches than Georgia (The Peach State).
(1889) Capital: Pierre.
Home to Mount Rushmore.
The Crazy Horse Memorial will be the world's largest sculpture when finished.
Wall Drug is one of the world's most famous roadside attractions.
The Corn Palace is decorated with actual crop art every year.
(1796) Capital: Nashville.
Nashville is the capital of country music.
Graceland (Elvis's home) is the second most visited house in the US.
Cotton candy was invented here by a dentist.
Great Smoky Mountains is the most visited National Park.
(1845) Capital: Austin.
King Ranch is larger than the entire state of Rhode Island.
Dr Pepper was invented in Waco in 1885.
The frozen margarita machine was invented in Dallas.
Uses its own power grid, separate from the rest of the US.
The phrase 'Don't Mess with Texas' started as an anti-litter campaign.
(1896) Capital: Salt Lake City.
The Great Salt Lake is 3 to 5 times saltier than the ocean.
Jell-O is the official state snack.
The Transcontinental Railroad was completed here (Golden Spike).
Has the greatest snow on earth (scientifically proven dry powder).
(1791) Capital: Montpelier.
The largest producer of maple syrup in the US.
Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream was founded here in a renovated gas station.
It is the only state capital without a McDonald's.
Billboards are completely banned.
(1788) Capital: Richmond.
Birthplace of 8 US Presidents, more than any other state.
Home to the Pentagon, the world's largest office building.
Jamestown was the first permanent English settlement (1607).
About 70% of the world's internet traffic flows through Northern Virginia.
(1889) Capital: Olympia.
Starbucks was founded at Pike Place Market in Seattle.
Produces more apples than any other state.
Home to the most glaciers in the contiguous US.
The Space Needle was built for the 1962 World's Fair.
(1863) Capital: Charleston.
The New River is actually one of the oldest rivers in the world.
The first Mother's Day was celebrated here in 1908.
Home to the pepperoni roll, a coal miner's lunch staple.
The New River Gorge Bridge is one of the highest in the western hemisphere.
(1848) Capital: Madison.
Produces more cheese than any other state.
The Green Bay Packers are the only community-owned NFL team.
Harley-Davidson was founded here in 1903.
Barbie is from the fictional town of Willows, Wisconsin.
(1890) Capital: Cheyenne.
The first state to grant women the right to vote (1869).
Has the lowest population of all 50 states.
Home to Devils Tower, the first National Monument.
Yellowstone was the world's first national park.
There are only two escalators in the entire state.
